intro: Limnophila × ludoviciana, commonly known as the swamp willow. It is a flowering plant native to wetland habitats in the southeastern United States. This species belongs to the family Lythraceae and is characterized by its slender, herbaceous stems and small, fragrant flowers. The leaves are opposite, ovate, and often have a reddish or purple tinge. It plays an important ecological role in stabilizing wetland soils and providing habitat for various aquatic and terrestrial organisms.
